questiontext.text:
A farm produces 4 types of fruit: watermelons, lemons, coconuts, and apples. The fruits’ masses follow normal distributions, with parameters dependent on the type of fruit.

Type of fruit _ _ Mean mass (g) _ _ Standard deviation of mass (g) _
watermelons 8659 568
lemons 119 18
coconuts 618 45
apples 198 32

One specimen of each type is weighed. The results are shown below.

specimen type _ _ Mass of specimen (g)
watermelon 7620
lemon 93.8
coconut 615.3
apple 216.6
  1. Calculate a zz score for the watermelon specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=-1.83:0.011}
  2. What percent of watermelons have less mass than the watermelon specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.0336:0.004}
  3. Calculate a zz score for the lemon specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=-1.4:0.011}
  4. What percent of lemons have less mass than the lemon specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.0808:0.004}
  5. Calculate a zz score for the coconut specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=-0.06:0.011}
  6. What percent of coconuts have less mass than the coconut specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.4761:0.004}
  7. Calculate a zz score for the apple specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.58:0.011}
  8. What percent of apples have less mass than the apple specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.719:0.004}
  9. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The watermelon specimen is most unusually large.~%0%The lemon specimen is most unusually large.~%0%The coconut specimen is most unusually large.~%100%The apple specimen is most unusually large.}
  10. {1:MULTICHOICE:%100%The watermelon specimen is most unusually small.~%0%The lemon specimen is most unusually small.~%0%The coconut specimen is most unusually small.~%0%The apple specimen is most unusually small.}
  11. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The watermelon specimen is most typically sized.~%0%The lemon specimen is most typically sized.~%100%The coconut specimen is most typically sized.~%0%The apple specimen is most typically sized.}
  12. {1:MULTICHOICE:%100%The watermelon specimen is most unusually sized.~%0%The lemon specimen is most unusually sized.~%0%The coconut specimen is most unusually sized.~%0%The apple specimen is most unusually sized.}

generalfeedback.text:
1. We use the formula for calculating the watermelon specimen’s zz score. z=7620−8659568=−1.83z = \frac{7620-8659}{568} = -1.83
  2. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<−1.83)=0.0336P(Z<-1.83) = 0.0336
  3. We use the formula for calculating the lemon specimen’s zz score. z=93.8−11918=−1.4z = \frac{93.8-119}{18} = -1.4
  4. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<−1.4)=0.0808P(Z<-1.4) = 0.0808
  5. We use the formula for calculating the coconut specimen’s zz score. z=615.3−61845=−0.06z = \frac{615.3-618}{45} = -0.06
  6. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<−0.06)=0.4761P(Z<-0.06) = 0.4761
  7. We use the formula for calculating the apple specimen’s zz score. z=216.6−19832=0.58z = \frac{216.6-198}{32} = 0.58
  8. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<0.58)=0.719P(Z<0.58) = 0.719
  9. We determine the maximum zz score is 0.580.58, which belongs to the apple. / . / . / .
  10. We determine the minimum zz score is −1.83-1.83, which belongs to the watermelon. / . / . / .
  11. We determine the minimum absolute zz score is 0.060.06, which belongs to the coconut. / . / . / .
  12. We determine the maximum absolute zz score is 1.831.83, which belongs to the watermelon. / . / . / .

Type of fruit _ _ Mean mass (g) _ _ Standard deviation of mass (g) _
coconuts 735 97
pineapples 1839 219
grapefruits 272 42
bananas 204 13

One specimen of each type is weighed. The results are shown below.

specimen type _ _ Mass of specimen (g)
coconut 830.1
pineapple 1806
grapefruit 294.3
banana 228.8
  1. Calculate a zz score for the coconut specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.98:0.011}
  2. What percent of coconuts have less mass than the coconut specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.8365:0.004}
  3. Calculate a zz score for the pineapple specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=-0.15:0.011}
  4. What percent of pineapples have less mass than the pineapple specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.4404:0.004}
  5. Calculate a zz score for the grapefruit specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.53:0.011}
  6. What percent of grapefruits have less mass than the grapefruit specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.7019:0.004}
  7. Calculate a zz score for the banana specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=1.91:0.011}
  8. What percent of bananas have less mass than the banana specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.9719:0.004}
  9. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The coconut specimen is most unusually large.~%0%The pineapple specimen is most unusually large.~%0%The grapefruit specimen is most unusually large.~%100%The banana specimen is most unusually large.}
  10. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The coconut specimen is most unusually small.~%100%The pineapple specimen is most unusually small.~%0%The grapefruit specimen is most unusually small.~%0%The banana specimen is most unusually small.}
  11. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The coconut specimen is most typically sized.~%100%The pineapple specimen is most typically sized.~%0%The grapefruit specimen is most typically sized.~%0%The banana specimen is most typically sized.}
  12. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The coconut specimen is most unusually sized.~%0%The pineapple specimen is most unusually sized.~%0%The grapefruit specimen is most unusually sized.~%100%The banana specimen is most unusually sized.}

generalfeedback.text:
1. We use the formula for calculating the coconut specimen’s zz score. z=830.1−73597=0.98z = \frac{830.1-735}{97} = 0.98
  2. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<0.98)=0.8365P(Z<0.98) = 0.8365
  3. We use the formula for calculating the pineapple specimen’s zz score. z=1806−1839219=−0.15z = \frac{1806-1839}{219} = -0.15
  4. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<−0.15)=0.4404P(Z<-0.15) = 0.4404
  5. We use the formula for calculating the grapefruit specimen’s zz score. z=294.3−27242=0.53z = \frac{294.3-272}{42} = 0.53
  6. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<0.53)=0.7019P(Z<0.53) = 0.7019
  7. We use the formula for calculating the banana specimen’s zz score. z=228.8−20413=1.91z = \frac{228.8-204}{13} = 1.91
  8. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<1.91)=0.9719P(Z<1.91) = 0.9719
  9. We determine the maximum zz score is 1.911.91, which belongs to the banana. / . / . / .
  10. We determine the minimum zz score is −0.15-0.15, which belongs to the pineapple. / . / . / .
  11. We determine the minimum absolute zz score is 0.150.15, which belongs to the pineapple. / . / . / .
  12. We determine the maximum absolute zz score is 1.911.91, which belongs to the banana. / . / . / .

questiontext.text:
Random variable XX is normally distributed with mean μ=260\mu = 260 and standard deviation σ=80\sigma = 80. X=N(260,80)X = \text{N}(260,\,80)

Note: The answers are determined using the values from the zz-table, where probabilities are rounded to the nearest 0.0001. However, the tolerance is large enough that you can use more exact methods.

  1. Evaluate P(X<116)P(X<116). {1:NUMERICAL:=0.0359:0.004}
  2. Evaluate P(X>188)P(X>188). {1:NUMERICAL:=0.8159:0.004}
  3. Evaluate P(116<X<188)P(116 < X < 188). {1:NUMERICAL:=0.1482:0.004}

generalfeedback.text:
Find the zz scores.

z1=116−26080=−1.8z_1 ~=~ \frac{116-260}{80} ~=~ -1.8

z2=188−26080=−0.9z_2 ~=~ \frac{188-260}{80} ~=~ -0.9

  1. Use the zz table to find P(Z<−1.8)=0.0359P(Z<-1.8) = 0.0359.
  2. Use the zz table, and rule of complements, to determine P(Z>−0.9)=0.8159P(Z>-0.9)=0.8159.
  3. Probability between two boundaries: P(−1.8<Z<−0.9)=P(Z<−0.9)−P(Z<−1.8)=0.1482P(-1.8<Z<-0.9) = P(Z<-0.9) - P(Z<-1.8) = 0.1482 Also, notice all three probabilities add to 1.

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 8.10 and standard deviation of 6.86.

That spinner will be spun 100 times, and the sum of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sum will be outside 54.88 units from the expected value?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will sum 100 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μ∑X=n⋅μX=(100)(8.1)=810\mu_{\sum X} ~=~ n\cdot \mu_X ~=~ (100)(8.1) ~=~ 810

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(6.86)⋅100=68.6\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (6.86)\cdot \sqrt{100} ~=~ 68.6

We find a zz score. z=54.8868.6=0.8z ~=~ \frac{54.88}{68.6} ~=~ 0.8

We find the probability. P(|∑X−810|>54.88)=P(|Z|>0.8)=0.4238P\left(\left|\sum X - 810 \right|> 54.88 \right) ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big|>0.8\right) ~=~ 0.4238

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|>z)=2−2⋅P(Z<z)P(|Z| > z) ~=~ 2-2\cdot P(Z<z)

generalfeedback.text:
When we will sum 100 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μ∑X=n⋅μX=(100)(7.85)=785\mu_{\sum X} ~=~ n\cdot \mu_X ~=~ (100)(7.85) ~=~ 785

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(4.6)⋅100=46\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (4.6)\cdot \sqrt{100} ~=~ 46

We find a zz score. z=727.5−78546=−1.25z ~=~ \frac{727.5-785}{46} ~=~ -1.25

We find the probability. P(∑X<727.5)=P(Z<−1.25)=0.1056P\left(\sum X < 727.5 \right) ~=~ P(Z<-1.25) ~=~ 0.1056

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 6.42 and standard deviation of 6.25.

That spinner will be spun 144 times, and the sum of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sum will be within 50.25 units from the expected value?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will sum 144 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μ∑X=n⋅μX=(144)(6.42)=924.48\mu_{\sum X} ~=~ n\cdot \mu_X ~=~ (144)(6.42) ~=~ 924.48

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(6.25)⋅144=75\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (6.25)\cdot \sqrt{144} ~=~ 75

We find a zz score. z=50.2575=0.67z ~=~ \frac{50.25}{75} ~=~ 0.67

We find the probability. P(|∑X−924.48|<50.25)=P(|Z|<0.67)=0.4972P\left(\left|\sum X - 924.48 \right|< 50.25 \right) ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big|<0.67\right) ~=~ 0.4972

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|<z)=2⋅P(Z<z)−1P(|Z| < z) ~=~ 2\cdot P(Z<z)-1

generalfeedback.text:

μ∑X=n⋅μX=(25)(6.93)=173.25\mu_{\sum X} ~=~ n\cdot \mu_X ~=~ (25)(6.93) ~=~ 173.25

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(5)⋅25=25\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (5)\cdot \sqrt{25} ~=~ 25

We find a zz score. z=10.2525=0.41z ~=~ \frac{10.25}{25} ~=~ 0.41

We find the probability. P(|∑X−173.25|>10.25)=P(|Z|>0.41)=0.6818P\left(\left|\sum X - 173.25 \right|> 10.25 \right) ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big|>0.41\right) ~=~ 0.6818

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|>z)=2−2⋅P(Z<z)P(|Z| > z) ~=~ 2-2\cdot P(Z<z)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 8.97 and standard deviation of 6.48.

That spinner will be spun 25 times, and the sum of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sum will be more than 183.75?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will sum 25 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μ∑X=n⋅μX=(25)(8.97)=224.25\mu_{\sum X} ~=~ n\cdot \mu_X ~=~ (25)(8.97) ~=~ 224.25

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(6.48)⋅25=32.4\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (6.48)\cdot \sqrt{25} ~=~ 32.4

We find a zz score. z=183.75−224.2532.4=−1.25z ~=~ \frac{183.75-224.25}{32.4} ~=~ -1.25

We find the probability. P(∑X>183.75)=P(Z>−1.25)=0.8944P\left(\sum X > 183.75 \right) ~=~ P(Z>-1.25) ~=~ 0.8944

In case you forgot, P(Z>z)=1−P(Z<z)P(Z > z) ~=~ 1 - P(Z<z)

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(3.75)⋅25=18.75\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (3.75)\cdot \sqrt{25} ~=~ 18.75

We find both zz scores. z1=108.5−110.7518.75=−0.12z_1 ~=~ \frac{108.5-110.75}{18.75} ~=~ -0.12

z2=143.75−110.7518.75=1.76z_2 ~=~ \frac{143.75-110.75}{18.75} ~=~ 1.76

We find the probability. P(108.5<∑X<143.75)=P(−0.12<Z<1.76)=0.5086P\left(108.5 < \sum X < 143.75 \right) ~=~ P\left(-0.12 < Z < 1.76\right) ~=~ 0.5086

In case you forgot, as long as z1<z2z_1<z_2, P(z1<Z<z2)=P(Z<z2)−P(Z<z1)P(z_1 < Z < z_2) ~=~ P(Z<z_2) - P(Z<z_1)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 3.94 and standard deviation of 2.70.

That spinner will be spun 36 times, and the sample mean of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sample mean will be outside 0.27 units from the expected value?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will average 36 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μX‾=μX=3.94\mu_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \mu_X ~=~ 3.94

σX‾=σXn=2.736=0.45\sigma_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \frac{\sigma_{X}}{\sqrt{n}} ~=~ \frac{2.7}{\sqrt{36}} ~=~ 0.45

We find a zz score. z=0.270.45=0.6z ~=~ \frac{0.27}{0.45} ~=~ 0.6

We find the probability. P(|X‾−3.94|>0.27)=P(|Z|>0.6)=0.5486P\left(\left|\bar{X}-3.94\right| > 0.27 \right) ~=~ P(|Z|>0.6) ~=~ 0.5486

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|>z)=2−2⋅P(Z<z)P(|Z| > z) ~=~ 2-2\cdot P(Z<z)

σX‾=σXn=3.3121=0.3\sigma_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \frac{\sigma_{X}}{\sqrt{n}} ~=~ \frac{3.3}{\sqrt{121}} ~=~ 0.3

We find a zz score. z=7.38−7.170.3=0.7z ~=~ \frac{7.38-7.17}{0.3} ~=~ 0.7

We find the probability. P(X‾<7.38)=P(Z<0.7)=0.758P\left(\bar{X} < 7.38 \right) ~=~ P(Z<0.7) ~=~ 0.758

σX‾=σXn=864=1\sigma_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \frac{\sigma_{X}}{\sqrt{n}} ~=~ \frac{8}{\sqrt{64}} ~=~ 1

We find a zz score. z=8.15−8.651=−0.5z ~=~ \frac{8.15-8.65}{1} ~=~ -0.5

We find the probability. P(X‾>8.15)=P(Z>−0.5)=0.3085P\left(\bar{X} > 8.15 \right) ~=~ P(Z>-0.5) ~=~ 0.3085

In case you forgot, P(Z>z)=1−P(Z<z)P(Z > z) ~=~ 1 - P(Z<z)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 4.74 and standard deviation of 2.00.

That spinner will be spun 100 times, and the sample mean of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sample mean will be within 0.25 units from the expected value?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will average 100 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μX‾=μX=4.74\mu_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \mu_X ~=~ 4.74

σX‾=σXn=2100=0.2\sigma_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \frac{\sigma_{X}}{\sqrt{n}} ~=~ \frac{2}{\sqrt{100}} ~=~ 0.2

We find a zz score. z=0.250.2=1.25z ~=~ \frac{0.25}{0.2} ~=~ 1.25

We find the probability. P(|X‾−4.74|<0.25)=P(|Z|<1.25)=0.7888P\left(\left|\bar{X}-4.74\right| < 0.25 \right) ~=~ P(|Z|<1.25) ~=~ 0.7888

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|<z)=2⋅P(Z<z)−1P(|Z| < z) ~=~ 2\cdot P(Z<z)-1

That spinner will be spun 625 times. What is the probability the number of successes will be less than 311.5?

generalfeedback.text:

Find the zz score. z=311.5−312.512.5=−0.08z ~=~ \frac{311.5-312.5}{12.5} ~=~ -0.08

Determine the probability. P(Z<−0.08)=0.4681P(Z<-0.08) = 0.4681

That spinner will be spun 625 times. What is the probability the number of successes will be between 300.5 and 309.5?

generalfeedback.text:
Use the de Moivre-Laplace Theorem, which tells us this binomial distribution is approximately normal. Determine the parameters. μ=np=(625)(0.5)=312.5\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (625)(0.5) ~=~ 312.5 σ=np(1−p)=(625)(0.5)(0.5)=12.5\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(625)(0.5)(0.5)} ~=~ 12.5

Find the zz scores. z1=300.5−312.512.5=−0.96z_1 ~=~ \frac{300.5-312.5}{12.5} ~=~ -0.96 z2=309.5−312.512.5=−0.24z_2 ~=~ \frac{309.5-312.5}{12.5} ~=~ -0.24

Determine the probability. P(−0.96<Z<−0.24)=0.2367P(-0.96<Z<-0.24) = 0.2367

In case you forgot, as long as z1<z2z_1<z_2, P(z1<Z<z2)=P(Z<z2)−P(Z<z1)P(z_1 < Z < z_2) ~=~ P(Z<z_2) - P(Z<z_1)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the chance of success is 0.84.

That spinner will be spun 525 times. What is the probability the proportion of successes will be less than 0.86?

generalfeedback.text:
Use the de Moivre-Laplace Theorem, which tells us this proportion-sampling distribution is approximately normal. Determine the parameters. μ=p=0.84\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.84 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.84)(0.16)525=0.016\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.84)(0.16)}{525}} ~=~ 0.016

Find the zz score. z=0.86−0.840.016=1.25z ~=~ \frac{0.86-0.84}{0.016} ~=~ 1.25

Determine the probability. P(Z<1.25)=0.8944P(Z<1.25) = 0.8944

questiontext.text:
Random variable XX is normally distributed with mean 9.099.09 and standard deviation 2.082.08.

Determine xx such that P(X>x)=0.9332P(X>x)=0.9332.

generalfeedback.text:
Determine the zz score that satisfies P(Z>z)=0.9332P(Z>z)=0.9332. P(Z>−1.5)=0.9332P(Z>-1.5) = 0.9332 So, z=−1.5z=-1.5.

Convert the zz score into an xx value. x=μ+zσ=9.09+(−1.5)(2.08)=5.97\begin{aligned} x &= \mu+z\sigma \\ &= 9.09+(-1.5)(2.08) \\ &= 5.97 \end{aligned}

So, P(X>5.97)=0.9332P(X>5.97) = 0.9332 and x=5.97x=5.97
